title: Trashigang District
text:
Trashigang District (<a href="Dzongkha">Dzongkha</a>: བཀྲ་ཤིས་སྒང་རྫོང་ཁག་; <a href="Wylie%20transliteration">Wylie</a>: "Bkra-shis-sgang rdzong-khag"; also spelled "Tashigang") is <a href="Bhutan">Bhutan</a>'s easternmost <a href="dzongkhag">dzongkhag</a> (district).
Culture.
Trashigang district is mainly <a href="Tshangla">Tshangla</a> (<a href="Sharchop%20people">Sharchop</a>)s, which means "easterner" in <a href="Dzongkha">Dzongkha</a>, the national language.
Languages.
The dominant language of Trashigang is <a href="Tshangla%20language">Tshangla (Sharchopkha)</a>, the "lingua franca" of eastern Bhutan. Two significant minority languages are spoken in the far eastern region of the district: the <a href="East%20Bodish%20languages">East Bodish</a> <a href="Dakpa%20language">Dakpa language</a> and the Southern Bodish <a href="Brokpa%20language">Brokpa language</a>. Dakpa is spoken by descendants of <a href="yak">yak</a>herding communities, and may in fact be a divergent dialect of <a href="Brokpa%20language">Brokpake</a>, heavily influenced by <a href="Dzala%20language">Dzalakha</a>.
Economy and education.
While it has no major urban area, Trashigang dzongkhag has the densest population in Bhutan. It used to be part of an important trade route connecting <a href="Assam">Assam</a> to <a href="Tibet">Tibet</a>, and still is a primary route for Bhutanese trade with India. Towns include <a href="Trashigang">Trashigang</a> (the district capital), <a href="Radi%2C%20Bhutan">Radi</a>, <a href="Rangjung">Rangjung</a>, and <a href="Phongmey">Phongmey</a>. The district produces a lot of <a href="rice">rice</a> and <a href="lavender">lavender</a>.
There are several tourist packages to Bhutan that include trips from <a href="Thimphu">Thimphu</a> to Trashigang, despite the 17-hour journey from the capital over the rough and dangerous <a href="Lateral%20Road">Lateral Road</a>.
Trashigang dzongkhag is also the site of <a href="Sherubtse%20College">Sherubtse College</a>, the original college within the <a href="Royal%20University%20of%20Bhutan">Royal University of Bhutan</a> system.
Landmarks.
<a href="Trashigang%20Dzong">Trashigang Dzong</a>, or fortress, was built in 1659 by the third <a href="Druk%20Desi">Druk Desi</a> Chögyal Mingyur Tenpa to defend against Tibetan invaders. Because of its altitude invading armies remarked that "it is not a dzong on the ground, it is in the sky".
An ancient "<a href="lhakhang">lhakhang</a>" or <a href="temple">temple</a> in the district, known for its <a href="rock%20garden">rock garden</a>, contains a sacred footprint said to be either that of <a href="Guru%20Rimpoche">Guru Rimpoche</a> or that of a "khandroma" (angel).
<a href="Rangjung">Rangjung</a>, 16 km east of the district capital, is the site of Rangjung Ösel Chöling Monastery, established by Dungse Garab Dorje Rinpoche in 1989. The temple contains particularly fine images of <a href="Padmasambhava">Padmasambhava</a>, <a href="Shantarakshita">Shantarakshita</a> and <a href="Trisong%20Detsen">Chögyal Trisong Detsen</a> (Khen-Lop-Chö sum).
Administrative divisions.
Trashigang Districts is divided into fifteen village blocks (or "<a href="gewog">gewog</a>s"):
Protected area.
The <a href="Sakteng%20Wildlife%20Sanctuary">Sakteng Wildlife Sanctuary</a>, one of <a href="List%20of%20protected%20areas%20of%20Bhutan">ten protected areas of Bhutan</a>, was created in part to protect the "<a href="migoi">migoi</a>", a type of yeti, in whose existence most Bhutanese believe. The sanctuary covers the eastern third of the district (the "gewogs" of <a href="Merag%20Gewog">Merag</a> and <a href="Sakten%20Gewog">Sakteng</a>), and is connected via <a href="biological%20corridor">biological corridor</a> to <a href="Khaling%20Wildlife%20Sanctuary">Khaling Wildlife Sanctuary</a> in <a href="Samdrup%20Jongkhar%20District">Samdrup Jongkhar District</a> to the south.
